prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I tell a buddy that no one wants his girlfriend to come to game night?
My group of friends have a once a month game night.  It’s mostly just the five of us getting drunk, playing cards or board games, and catching up.   It’s probably sad, but it used to be the highlight of my month.  

One of my friends has a girlfriend who for the last four times has tagged along.  None of us minded when he first asked if she could come, but she’s made these get together completely un enjoyable.  

She’s nice enough I guess, but she’s insanely annoying.   She always has to be the center of attention.  She talks about herself and her opinion almost nonstop and she’s really not that interesting so it doesn’t make for good conversation.  If someone is talking, she will interrupt and find a way to bring it back to her.  If the person keeps talking she will just talk over them.  I’ve sat there and watched her do it and raise her voice on purpose just to be louder than the person talking.  

Another thing that’s been awkward for me personally is that she tries to make me a stereotype.  I’m gay.  I’m not the “gay bff” type of guy though.  Yet she keeps trying to make me into hers.  She’s always getting weirdly touchy feely with me.  She tries to have “girl talk” with me.  One time she learned that I was going out to a gay bar and shows up uninvited and basically followed me around and ruined my entire night.   I’ve tried to be tactful with her since she’s my buddy’s girl, but she does not get the hint.  One time I went so far as to tell her that I don’t have any female friends because I just really only get along with guys (lie), but in one ear and out the other.  

No one except her boyfriend wants her there.   The rest of us have all talked about it.  None of us like her.   We just don’t know how to tell him.  I’m a rip the bandaid off kind of guy and just want to take him out for a beer and tell him.  I would be nice about it.  I already know the gist of what I would say.  “The group dynamic has just changed with a girl in the mix.  We’d like to make it a guys only night and maybe get together with you guys as a couple a different night. “.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. Let's break down the situation. The person is part of a group that has monthly game nights, which used to be fun but have become unpleasant since a friend's girlfriend started attending. The main issues are that the girlfriend is very self-centered, interrupts conversations, and makes the gay author uncomfortable by trying to stereotype him. The author and the group don't want her there anymore and are considering confronting the friend directly.

First, the author's actions: they plan to tell their friend that the group wants to make game night guys-only. The question is whether this is wrong. The arguments for the author being in the wrong might include that they're being dishonest or that they're excluding someone without a valid reason. The girlfriend is part of a couple, so the friend might feel excluded if they're told to have separate plans with his girlfriend. Also, maybe the author is being too harsh without giving the girlfriend another chance or addressing her behavior directly with her instead of her boyfriend.

On the other hand, the author and their friends have clearly been uncomfortable for months. The girlfriend's behavior is affecting the group dynamic and causing personal distress to the author. They've tried to be tactful, and the group agrees they don't want her there. The author's approach is to be honest but sensitive, suggesting an alternative meeting with the couple. That seems reasonable because the group has a right to their comfort and to set boundaries for their social gatherings.

But wait, is it fair to exclude someone because of another person's behavior? The group is doing it to protect their own enjoyment, which is understandable. However, the approach of being direct might come off as harsh, even if well-intentioned. The author might have considered other options, like discussing the issue with the girlfriend directly, but the situation involves the friend's partner, so that's complicated. The author's actions could be seen as necessary to restore the group's previous enjoyment, so maybe they're justified.

Also, the author's personal experience with the girlfriend's unwanted attention and stereotyping adds to the justification. The group's decision to make changes isn't just about preference but about addressing harassment-like behavior. So, the author isn't in the wrong for wanting to address this, especially since they've tried to be polite and the group is united in their discomfort.
